only 63 local deaths were associated with confirmed pH1N1 infection during the first wave between April and December 2009. 127 excess deaths 6 compared with around 1000 excess deaths associated with seasonal influenza every year in Hong Kong. the agespecific risk of severe illness and death was estimated on a perinfection basis (7, 8) Identification of risk factors Healthcare workers were not at particularly high risk of infection (17, 22) Intention to receive the pandemic vaccine was low in the general population. the highest pH1N1 infection attack rates occurred among schoolage children. investigations of school outbreaks tend to overestimate transmissibility because of selection bias. serologic studies allowed robust inference on the cumulative incidence of infection through the first wave of pH1N1, 7, 8, 11, 19, 26 and when combined with surveillance data on severe cases allowed accurate estimates of the severity profile of pH1N1. the unique setting in Hong Kong facilitated some of the studies discussed here. but the uniqueness was also a limitation when considering the generalization of research findings. 68 There are some limitations of our review. a rapid and comprehensive research response to pH1N1 in Hong Kong is now being used to revise and update pandemic plans and preparedness. the experiences of the research response in Hong Kong may also provide a template for the research response to emerging and reemerging disease epidemics.
